Description.val: Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) Family of Vehicles (FoV) is a joint U.S. Army and U.S. Marine Corps program. JLTV is a FoV capable of performing multiple mission roles that will provide protected, sustained, networked mobility for personnel and payloads across the full Range of Military Operations (ROMO). JLTV objectives include increased protection and performance over the legacy HMMWV fleet, minimizing ownership costs by maximizing commonality, fuel efficiency and reliability. The commonality of components, maintenance procedures, training, etc, among vehicle variants is expected to be inherent in FoV solutions across mission variants to minimize total ownership cost. Unique service requirements have been minimized.

Justification.val:
FY 2014 Base Appropriation: N/A

FY 2015 Base Appropriation: $7.500M
Planned projects include the procurement of 7 LRIP assets, kit procurement, government and contractor support, test and evaluation associated with LRIP, development of publications and technical data and fielding. The kits support the baseline vehicle by providing the warfighter with the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operation, communications/C4I, winches, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations.

FY 2016 Base Appropriation Request: $79.429M
Planned projects include the procurement of 109 LRIP assets, kit procurement, government and contractor support, test and evaluation associated with LRIP, development of publications and technical data and fielding. The kits support the baseline vehicle by providing the warfighter with the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operation, communications/C4I, winches, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations. The increase ($71.929M) in funding from FY 2015 to FY 2016 is due to the ramp-up in production of JLTV (102 additional vehicles compared to FY 2015), the initiation of the LRIP phase test program, procurement of initial spares and the shifting of programmatic support from RDT&E to procurement funding.

Name.@footnote: MS C is scheduled 4Q FY 2015 with a subsequent contract award in 4Q FY 2015; the production vendor has not been determined. This applies across all fiscal years and each vehicle variant.

MS C is scheduled 4Q FY 2015 with subsequent contract award in 4Q FY 2015; the manufacturer, award date, and annual production rates are yet to be determined. This applies across all fiscal years and each vehicle variant. The production rates in this exhibit are shown as annual rates.  The production rates in the Armys P-form is shown as a monthly rate.

FiscalYear.@footnote: The final RFP for the LRIP contract was released on 12 December 2014, this RFP covers the four variants and all option years. MS C is scheduled 4Q FY 2015 with a subsequent contract award in 4Q FY 2015; the production vendor has not been determined. It is intended to be a single award, fixed price contract consisting of a three year LRIP period with an option for five years of FRP deliveries.   This applies across all fiscal years and for each vehicle variant.

ProcQuantity.@footnote: Notional production schedule for FY 2016 to FY 2020; LRIP Contract Award scheduled for 4Q FY 2015. The production schedule will be updated to reflect the selected vendor in the budget submissions after the LRIP/FRP Contract Award. Army quantities not broken out by variant but will be broken out by variant for Presidents Budget submission.  Army quantities only submitted for FY16. This applies across all fiscal years and each vehicle variant.

Due to U.S. Marine Corps' procuring 0 Heavy Guns Carriers in FY 2015 there is no delivery schedule shown; however, the U.S. Army is procuring 19 vehicles in FY 2015 spread across the year delivery period.

Due to U.S. Marine Corps' procuring 0 Close Combat Weapons Carriers in FY 2015 there is no delivery schedule shown; however, the U.S. Army is procuring 25 vehicles in FY 2015 spread across the year delivery period.

Due to U.S. Marine Corps' procuring 0 Utility Vehicles in FY 2015 there is no delivery schedule shown; however, the U.S. Army is procuring 46 vehicles in FY 2015 spread across the year delivery period.

Name.@footnote: Kits are not categorized in Flyaway costs because they are not considered part of prime mission equipment.
Funding for Program Management increases from FY 2015 to FY 2016 due to the shift of program management costs from RDT&E to procurement funding.
Funding increases between FY 2015 and FY 2016 due to the ramp-up of LRIP assets being produced.

FY 2015 funding provides for the development of the LRIP test plan. FY 2016 funding increases due to the finalization of the LRIP test plan and the initiation of the LRIP test program which will include a ramp-up of test efforts.
